sect1.title: 96 Gastroenteritis Viruses*
sect1.para: MUSA HINDIYEH, SHUBHAGATA DAS, AND SHERRY DUNBAR

Acute viral gastroenteritis (AVG) is a common self-limiting illness affecting infants, children, and adults worldwide. Indeed, viral diarrheal diseases are the leading cause of morbidity worldwide, particularly in children less than 5 years of age (1–3). In developed countries, AVG is associated with significant morbidity in children and the elderly, while in developing countries these infections have been associated with high morbidity and mortality, especially in infants (4). The World Health Organization (WHO) has estimated that around 500,000 die each year as a result of AVG worldwide (5). Patients with AVG usually present with abdominal pain, diarrhea, nausea, vomiting, weight loss, and dehydration (6). The clinical manifestation of AVG is due to the effects that the virus and its specific cytotoxins exert on the enterocytes of the intestine (7). Viral replication in the enterocytes causes alteration in brush border enzyme production, thus causing nutrient malabsorption and osmotic diarrhea (4). Moreover, viral toxins can lead to direct damage and lysis of the enterocytes and the intestinal villi, thus causing transudative loss of fluids into the intestine (8). The destruction and loss of cell function can lead to electrolyte abnormalities which can in turn lead to the loss of transporter functionality (8). AVG can be triggered by many viruses, most often rotavirus, caliciviruses (norovirus and sapovirus), enteric adenoviruses 40/41, and astroviruses (9). However, in recent years, with the advancement of next-generation sequencing (NGS), particularly from stool samples from patients with AVG, the number of potential viral pathogens causing AVG has expanded tremendously. Several viral pathogens are included in the list of potential causative agents of AVG. These include recovirus, tusavirus, bufavirus, polyomavirus, klassevirus/salivirus, Saffold virus, and cosavirus (10–18). This chapter discusses the latest developments in the field of diagnosing common human AVG.

sect1.title: Rotaviruses
sect1.para: Rotaviruses (RVs) are members of theReoviridae family, currently classified into nine species (rotavirus A, B, C, D, F, G, H, I, and J) (Table 1). The RV capsid contains an 11-segment double-stranded RNA (dsRNA) genome (19). RV species are classified based on their host range, sequence analysis of the conserved genome segments (1, 6) of member viruses, and the serological cross-reactivity of the group-specific antigen (VP6) that is present in the middle of the capsid. On the molecular level, it has been suggested that a cutoff value of 53% of the VP6 amino acid sequence firmly permits differentiation into the distinct RV species (20, 21). The rapid increase in use of molecular techniques worldwide has made RV genome sequencing the gold standard for classifying the virus (22). The RV species are commonly referred to as RV groups; RV-A, RV-B, RV-C, and RV-H groups are known to infect animals and humans, whereas the RV-D, RV-E, RV-F, RV-G, RV-I, and RV-J groups infect only animals (20).

Of the four RV groups that can infect humans, RV-A is the most relevant group in terms of epidemiological impact on human public health (23). RV-A classification is established by a dual typing system, based on immunological reaction and the structure of the two structural external proteins, VP4 (P genotype) and VP7 (G genotypes), which bind their neutralizing antibodies independently (24). Currently, at least 41 G genotypes and 57 P genotypes of RV-A have been reported in humans and animals, of which at least 60 combinations have been identified in humans and animals (25). A whole RV viral genome sequencing classification nomenclature has also been developed to describe RV genome constellation of strains: Gx-P[x]-Ix-Rx-Cx-Mx-Ax-Nx-Tx-Ex-Hx, denoting the VP7-VP4-VP6-VP1-VP2-VP3-NSP1-NSP2-NSP3-NSP4-NSP5/6 genes, with x referring to the various recognized genotypes for each gene. There are three major genotype constellations: Wa-like (G1-P[8]-I1-R1-C1-M1-A1-N1-T1-E1-H1), DS-1-like (G2-P[4]-I2-R2-C2-M2-A2-N2-T2-E2-H2), and AU-1-like (G3-P[9]-I3-R3-C3-M3-A3-N3-T3-E3-H3) (26). Globally, the most common G and P genotype combinations that account for 90% of infections in humans were G1P[8], G2[P4], G3[P8], G4[P8], G9[P8], and G12P[8] (27).

sect1.title: Caliciviruses
sect1.para: TheCaliciviridae family, which includes seven genera, is a genetically diverse family of viruses infecting a wide range of mammalian host species (Table 1). Of these genera, Norovirus (NoV) and Sapovirus (SaV) have been associated with human disease (28). Both NoV and SaV are associated with acute gastroenteritis (AGE) in humans and animals.

sect2.title: Noroviruses
sect2.para: Phylogenetically, NoVs can be segregated into different genogroups as well as P (polymerase) groups. Furthermore, NoVs can be further segregated into different genotypes and P-types based on the amino acid diversity of the VP1 gene and the nucleotide diversity of the RNA-dependent-RNA polymerase (RdRp) region of the ORF1, respectively (29). Based on that, currently the number of norovirus genogroups is 10 (GI through GX) and the number of genotypes is 49 (9 GI, 27 GII, 3 GIII, 2 GIV, 2 GV, 2 GVI, 1 GVII, 1 GVIII, 1 GIX, and 1 GX) (29). On the other hand, there are 60 P-types (14 GI, 37 GII, 2 GIII, 1 GIV, 2 GV, 2 GVI, 1 GVII, and 1 GX) (29). Humans can be infected with genogroups GI, GII, GIV, GVIII, and GIX, of which GI and GII are the most commonly detected genogroups. NoVs from other genogroups have been detected in a broad range of animals including bats (GX), rodents (GV), cats and dogs (GIV, GVI, and GVII), and cattle and sheep (GIII) (30).

sect2.title: Sapovirus
sect2.para: Sequence analysis of the SaV VP1 gene revealed that SaVs are classified into at least 19 genogroups (GI through GXIX), of which GI, GII, GIV, and GV are associated with human infections (31, 32). The remaining genogroups have been detected in swine (GIII and GV through GXI), dogs (GXIII), mink (GXII), bats (GXIV, GXVI through GXIX), sea lions (GV), and rats (GXV) (33). The four SaV genogroups, GI, GII, GIV, and GV, are currently subdivided into seven (GI.1 through GI.7), eight (GII.1 through GII.8), one (GIV.1), and two (GV.1, GV.2) genotypes, respectively (31–34).

sect1.title: Human Enteric Adenovirus
sect1.para: TheAdenoviridae family is a large family of viruses segregated into nine species/subgroups (A to I) (35). Within the subgroups, more than 90 genotypes have been identified. The initial 51 serotypes were determined by neutralization assays, while genotypes 52 to 90 were determined after bioinformatics analysis of the whole human adenovirus (HAdV) genome sequence (36). HAdV types 40/41 belong to subgroup F and have long been established as agents of pediatric gastroenteritis, causing 5 to 20% of AGE in young children (37).

sect1.title: Astroviruses
sect1.para: Astroviruses (AsVs) belong to theAstroviridae family (4, 38) (Table 1). This family is divided into two genera based on the host origin, Mamastrovirus and Avastrovirus, infecting mammalian and avian species, respectively (39). The Mamastrovirus genus that infects mammalian species is divided into two genogroups, GI (10 genotypes) and GII (9 genotypes). Human AsVs (HAsVs) are classified into eight genotypes based on sequence analysis of the capsid precursor protein (ORF2), where genotype HAsV-1 and HAsV-2 are the most common types circulating worldwide, and HAsV-7 and HAsV-8 are very rare genotypes (38). Two novel genotypes (HAstV-MLB and HAstV-VA/HMO) of uncertain role in diarrheal disease have also been reported (39). The HAsV genotypes correlate with the HAsV serotypes, based on viral neutralization assays.

sect1.title: Other Viruses Causing Gastroenteritis
sect1.para: Other less common enteric viruses that have been associated with AVG include Aichi viruses, which are members of thePicornaviridae family (40). Two case-control studies found Aichi viruses in diarrheic patients; however, the Aichi virus prevalence (0.5% and 1.8%) was too low to find significant association with diarrhea (40–42). Coronaviruses and toroviruses, two genera in the Coronaviridae family, have also been associated with diarrhea and frequently observed in immunocompromised patients (43). Furthermore, SARS-CoV-2 has also been associated with gastroenteritis. A recently reported meta-analysis revealed that 17.6% of patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection had gastrointestinal symptoms (44). Picobirnaviruses, which belong to the Picobirnaviridae family, were first detected in feces of children with AVG. However, their low prevalence and high sequence diversity in samples from AVG patients have limited the likelihood that they are actually causing AVG outbreaks (45). Bocavirus, within the Parvoviridae family, has also been associated with AVG (46, 47).

sect1.title: Rotavirus
sect1.para: RV is a nonenveloped, segmented dsRNA virus that encodes six nonstructural proteins (NSP1 through NSP6) and six structural proteins (VP1 through 4, VP6, and VP7) (48). The structural viral proteins (VPs) are assembled into an icosahedral capsid that is formed from three concentric layers protecting the 11 genomic segments, the viral RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (VP1), and the viral capping enzyme (VP3) (49, 50). The three RV capsid layers are assembled from 60 dimers of inner capsid (VP2), 260 trimers of the middle layer protein (VP6), and 780 monomers of the glycosylated VP7 protein (22, 48). The entire spherical RV viral particle is approximately 70 to 100 nm in diameter (Fig. 1C) (51). The nonstructural viral protein, NSP4, is considered to be a viral enterotoxin (52). This enterotoxin has both secretory and subsequent antisecretory actions, which result in loss of Cl– in the intestinal lumen, thus increasing osmotic imbalance and drawing more water into the gut lumen (52).

sect1.title: Caliciviruses (NoV and SaV)
sect1.para: Caliciviruses are nonenveloped, round, small virus particles of 27 to 40 nm in diameter (32). The capsid, which is composed of 90 dimers of the major structural protein VP1, is arranged on a T=3 icosahedral lattice. The architecture of the calicivirus capsid presents 32 distinct cup-shaped depressions (28). The calicivirus capsid protects a linear positive-sense single-stranded RNA (ssRNA) genome of 6.4 to 8.5 kb in size. The NoV viral genome is organized into two or three major open reading frames (ORFs) with a viral protein (VPg) that is covalently linked to the 5′ terminus of the genomic RNA and has a 3′-end poly(A) tail. The ORFs encode the different structural and nonstructural proteins (28). The SaV genome is slightly different in that the sequences encoding the nonstructural and capsid proteins are fused into one large ORF. SaVs have the typical morphology of caliciviruses with the “star of David” appearance composed of cup-shaped depressions on the surface of the virus, while NoV possesses a smoother surface structure and therefore is called a “small round-structured virus” (Fig. 1B and D) (32).

sect1.title: Human Enteric Adenoviruses 40/41
sect1.para: The HAdV family of viruses got its name from the Greek wordaden, meaning “gland,” after their original isolation from adenoid tissue. The virus was also called “adenoid-associated virus.” HAdVs are nonenveloped viral particles, with a linear double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) of 26 to 45 kbp, and belong to the family Adenoviridae, genus Mastadenovirus (35). The HAdV genome encodes more than 30 structural and nonstructural proteins and has a 55-kDa protein at its 5′ end. The HAdV virion particle is approximately 70 to 100 nm in diameter. The HAdV capsid exhibits a characteristic icosahedral capsid layer of 252 capsomeres, of which 240 have a 6-fold symmetry (hexons) and form facets, while 12 have a 5-fold symmetry (pentons) and form vertices (53). Fiber-like projections protruding from the pentameric penton base proteins are responsible for host receptor binding (Fig. 1A). The capsid surrounds a DNA-containing core that consists of a single-copy viral DNA genome with other viral proteins (terminal protein, polypeptide, PVII, and pX) (53).

sect1.title: Astroviruses
sect1.para: HAsVs are small, round, nonenveloped, positive-sense ssRNA viruses with a 6.4- to 7.3-kb genome length (4, 12). The virus has a typical five- or six-pointed star-like appearance (astron = star in Greek). The structure of the virus has some resemblance to caliciviruses but a strong resemblance to hepatitis E virus (Fig. 1E). The HAsV genome encodes three ORFs named, from the 5′ end to the 3′ end, ORF1a, 1b, and 2. These three ORFs encode for serine protease, RNA-dependent RNA polymerase (RdRp), and capsid precursor protein, respectively (12).

sect2.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY AND TRANSMISSION
sect2.para: Acute viral gastroenteritis (AVG) is the most common diarrheal disease worldwide, infecting males and females equally. Severe illness is seen mainly in children younger than 5 years of age, with peak incidence in children between the ages of 6 months and 2 years. Sporadic illness and outbreaks in healthy adults, the elderly population, and immunocompromised patients have been reported (54). AVG causative agents can be transmitted by symptomatic patients and even by asymptomatic carriers who can transmit virus before onset of symptoms (55–58). In general, AVG agents are transmitted by the fecal-oral route; however, RV and NoV airborne transmission has been hypothesized in some gastroenteritis outbreaks (59–64). More recently, Ghosh et al. reported that in the suckling mouse model, enteric viruses could productively and persistently infect mouse salivary glands, reaching viral loads comparable to that in the intestines (65). This is important for human transmission, as saliva from infected infants directly transmits enteric viruses to their mother’s mammary glands through backflow during suckling. This can lead to a rapid increase in maternal milk secretory IgA antibodies. Thus, this report identifies a new route for enteric viral transmission. This could have significant implications for therapeutics, viral transmission, and patient diagnosis (65). Enteric viruses are stable over a wide range of temperature and pH, and even after heating, drying, and freezing, they can survive on human hands and inanimate objects for an extended period. Contaminated food and water can act as common sources of gastrointestinal infections (66, 67). Food can be contaminated by food handlers with gastroenteritis. In addition, water and shellfish may become contaminated with sewage. AVG occurs throughout the year with predominant activity in the fall and winter seasons (68–70).

figure.title: FIGURE 1 (MCM 12 Edition page 1658): Electron micrographs of the major gastroenteritis viruses. (A) adenovirus, (B) norovirus, (C) rotavirus, (D) sapovirus, (E) astrovirus.

sect1.title: Rotavirus
sect1.para: RV is the leading cause of severe dehydrating diarrhea in children between 6 months and 2 years of age and is a major cause of childhood deaths in developing countries. RV shedding in the patient’s stool occurs prior to the onset of symptoms and continues following the cessation of diarrhea. RV activity usually occurs in the fall/winter seasons in temperate climates and throughout the year in tropical climates. Before the introduction of RV vaccination, RV was the most common cause of AVG requiring medical attention. Countries that implemented RV vaccination witnessed a drastic drop in the number of RV pediatric AGE cases. The RV positivity rate in stool samples dropped from 30% to 10% (27). However, RV still circulates in older children and adults (19, 25, 71, 72). RVs are generally species-specific, but cross-species transmission has been reported, opening the door for the possibility of zoonotic infections (73–76).

sect1.title: Norovirus
sect1.para: NoV is a highly contagious virus that is capable of causing AGE in individuals of all ages throughout the year (77). It is the most important cause of nonbacterial AGE in both developing and developed countries (78). Sporadic infections can occur, particularly in young children (1, 2, 4, 57). Moreover, NoV is well known to cause outbreaks as a result of the ingestion of contaminated water or food or from fomites. NoV outbreaks mainly occur in closed communities and in a variety of settings like hospitals, schools, restaurants, and nursing homes (79). In countries that introduced RV in their childhood vaccination repertoire, NoV has become the leading cause of AGE requiring medical attention (80). Depending on the study, the detection of NoV-positive stool samples from patients with AGE ranged between 15 and 20% (78, 81–86).

sect1.title: Sapovirus
sect1.para: SaV is a childhood viral disease causing AGE in infants and toddlers year-round (9, 32). The clinical presentation is usually milder than RV. In patients less than 2 years of age and requiring medical intervention, SaV is usually detected in 5% of the stool samples (87).

sect1.title: Astrovirus
sect1.para: HAsV usually circulates in the winter season and cause infections in people of all age groups. HAsV has been well reported to cause outbreaks in closed populations, and sporadic HAsV AGE has been reported in children less than 4 years of age (88–93). Depending on the setting and the diagnostic tools utilized, HAsV infection has been linked to 2 to 10% of pediatric AVG. Asymptomatic infections are common in all ages.

sect1.title: Enteric Adenovirus
sect1.para: HAdV (40/41) predominantly affects children less than 5 years of age and circulates throughout the year, with peak activity in the summer season (89, 90, 94). Depending on the country, HAdV positivity in stool can range between 5 and 10% in children less than 2 years of age who present for medical attention. HAdV viral particles can also be present in stool samples of asymptomatic patients (95). HAdV can cause prolonged or chronic diarrhea in immunocompromised patients, especially in stem cell transplant patients (96).

sect1.title: Mixed Viral Infections
sect1.para: With the advancement of molecular diagnostic techniques, the detection of multiple pathogens in patients’ stool samples with AGE is not uncommon. Depending on the study, 5 to 15% of the children with AGE have mixed viral infection (97, 98). The clinical significance of mixed viral infections is not well understood. The presence of two or more viral agents in the patient stool sample does not appear to influence the clinical presentation.

sect2.title: CLINICAL SIGNIFICANCE
sect2.para: Most viral enteric infections are asymptomatic. However, AVG can become dangerous if it leads to dehydration. By the age of 2 years, virtually all children will have had at least one symptomatic episode of AGE. Symptoms usually start 12 hours to 10 days after exposure to the virus and can last from 3 to 9 days (4, 90). Patients with AGE usually present with loose or watery diarrhea that consists of three or more bowel movements per day of rapid onset. Visible blood or mucus in the patients’ stool samples are uncommon in AVG and should prompt the physician to think about a nonviral etiology. Diarrhea is usually accompanied by nausea, mild fever, vomiting, anorexia, headache, myalgia, or abdominal pain (99, 100). Patients usually complain of sudden onset of symptoms over 1 to 2 hours. Symptoms usually last for less than a week, with most patients improving after the first 3 days. Patient symptoms that last for more than 2 weeks are considered chronic symptoms and do not classify as AGE.

Severe RV infections with prolonged viral shedding have been reported in immunocompromised children with T-cell immunodeficiency, cancer, and severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) and in recipients of hematopoietic cell or solid organ transplants (101). In rare cases, the virus can disseminate systemically and involve other organ systems (102).

NoV and HAdV illnesses can be life-threatening in immunocompromised patients (103, 104). Several studies have reported chronic diarrhea with prolonged viral shedding in stool samples of patients who underwent hematopoietic stem cell and solid organ transplants. Treatment options for severe HAdV infection include reducing the immunosuppressive therapies, intravenous immunoglobulins, and administration of the antiviral cidofovir (105).

Overall, there are no effective antivirals that can be used for the treatment of AVG. Supportive treatment involves rehydration therapy, as the restoration of electrolyte balance is the most important procedure for severely dehydrated cases and for reducing mortality in developing countries.

Given the substantial worldwide burden of rotavirus diarrhea, the development of pediatric rotavirus vaccines becomes a priority. The concept of developing rotavirus vaccines was supported by epidemiological observations showing that infection with rotavirus induces natural protection from subsequent reinfection. In 2006, two oral live-attenuated rotavirus vaccines were licensed and became available globally (26, 49, 51, 95): the pentavalent RotaTeq (Merck & Co., Inc., Whitehouse Station, NJ) and monovalent Rotarix (GlaxoSmithKline-GSK) vaccines. The pentavalent rotavirus (RotaTeq) vaccine is based on a bovine rotavirus strain containing five single-gene reassortant strains expressing proteins for human serotypes G1, G2, G3, G4, and P[8] (106). RotaTeq reduced hospitalization and emergency department visits by 94.5%. The monovalent (Rotarix) vaccine is based on an attenuated strain of human rotavirus G1P[8]. Rotarix vaccine efficacy was 85% against severe RV gastroenteritis (107).

Two additional oral live-attenuated rotavirus vaccines were developed in India and received WHO pre-qualification in 2018: Rotavac (Bharat Biotech International Ltd., Hyderabad, India) and Rotasiil (Serum Institute of India, Pune, India) (108–111). Rotavac (Bharat Biotech) is a monovalent vaccine based on the 116E rotavirus strain, a naturally occurring reassortant strain G9P[11] containing 1 bovine rotavirus gene P[11] and 10 human rotavirus genes. Rotavac vaccine efficacy against severe RV gastroenteritis was 53.6% (108). Rotasiil (Serum Institute of India) is a live oral bovine-human reassortant pentavalent (BRV-PV) rotavirus vaccine including serotypes G1, G2, G3, G4, and G9 (110, 112). Vaccine efficacy against very severe RV gastroenteritis increased to 60.5%.

Other than the licensed RV vaccines, there are currently no available vaccines for the other AVG pathogens. Major effort is being invested to develop NoV vaccines (113). However, the development of a broadly effective NoV vaccine remains difficult, owing to the wide genetic and antigenic diversity of this family. Among the NoV vaccine candidates that are currently under clinical studies are the recombinant, nonreplicating VP1-based virus-like particles (VLPs) that mimic major antigenic features of NoV. Initial investigations revealed that the vaccines have proven safety, immunogenicity, and protective efficacy, supporting a high likelihood of a useful NoV vaccine in the near future.

sect2.title: COLLECTION, TRANSPORT, AND STORAGE OF SPECIMENS
sect2.para: Collecting an adequate sample is fundamental for rapid and accurate AVG diagnosis, thus avoiding extra cost and multiple, useless investigations. Accurate diagnosis of AVG starts with the collection of the stool sample as early as possible in the disease process, considering the short duration of viral shedding. Liquid diarrhea stool samples, preferably 10 ml, should be collected in a leakproof, clean container after the onset of AVG, between day 1 and 4 of the illness, when viral shedding is high (114, 115). The challenge of collecting and transporting bulk stool samples has paved the way for evaluating rectal swabs for the diagnosis of AVG. Rectal swabs have been reported to be as suitable for molecular diagnosis of the viral agents causing AVG as stool samples, especially in the early phase of the infection (116–123).

Patient specimens must be transported to the laboratory as soon as possible, within 1 to 2 hours of sample collection. Stool samples in a leakproof container should be placed in a waterproof bag with tissue or other blotting material to absorb any potential leakage. Specimens that need to be transported to a referral lab should be transported at 4°C in an insulated box (114, 115). Patient stool samples can be stored at 4°C pending testing for 48 hours. For longer storage (months to years), the samples must be stored at –80°C (114, 115). Making aliquots of stored samples at –80°C is recommended to avoid multiple freeze-thaw cycles. Stool samples must not be frozen if examination by electron microscopy is anticipated. Moreover, delays in storing stool samples at the appropriate temperatures can affect downstream molecular diagnostic analysis because of RNA degradation in RNA viruses.
Vomitus can supplement stool samples for the detection of gastrointestinal viruses. However, vomitus samples alone cannot be routinely used for enteric viral testing.

For epidemiological and research studies, serum samples can be used for the detection of gastrointestinal virus IgG antibodies. Acute-phase serum samples should be collected as soon as possible after onset of illness and then tested simultaneously with collected convalescent-phase serum. Processed serum specimens should be stored at –20°C pending side-by-side analysis of the patient’s acute and convalescent serum samples. Repeat freeze-thawing should be avoided, and specimens should not be stored in frost-free freezers.

sect1.title: Electron Microscopy
sect1.para: Electron microscopy (EM) has been traditionally used for the direct detection and visualization of viral gastroenteritis pathogens due to its nanometer-scale resolution (124). Intact viral particles are visualized by negative staining on a support grid, where the viral particles appear as lighter structures surrounded by a dark background. Since the common human AVG pathogens have different structures, EM has been useful in determining the viral agent in patient stool samples (Fig. 1) (125). EM can be used for the direct screening of stool samples for enteric viruses which have different structures, shape, and size. While EM has the distinct advantage of detecting a wide range of gastrointestinal viral agents, the sensitivity of this method is low, requiring a minimum of 106 viral particles per ml (115, 124).

To improve EM sensitivity, airfuge techniques or immunoconcentration procedures have been used to visualize most of the gastrointestinal virions. High-speed centrifugation at 100,000 ×g for 1 hour is used to concentrate the viral particles into a pellet that can be used for visualizing the virus particles by EM. In general, EM requires highly skilled microscopists and expensive equipment, making it not feasible for routine viral diagnosis and limited to research.

Immune EM (IEM) has also been used to improve EM sensitivity. IEM uses specific antibodies to aggregate the viral particles in the stool sample suspension, thus improving the diagnostic capability of EM (124, 126). IEM has been used to differentiate between the morphologically identical rotavirus groups A, B, and C (124, 127–129). Still, this technique is laborious, time-consuming, and too cumbersome to be widely useful for clinical diagnostics. To simplify and increase the IEM viral particle detection limit, solid-phase IEM (SPIEM) has been used to capture viral particles onto a solid grid. For AVG diagnosis, SPIEM that utilizes protein A, goat anti-human immunoglobulin M (IgM), and human serum has been used to serotype astroviruses, noroviruses, and rotaviruses (130–133). However, the limited availability of antibodies specific for the different viral agents hampers the use of this technique (130–133).

sect1.title: Antigen Detection Assays
sect1.para: The utilization of rapid and sensitive techniques to diagnose the causative agent of AVG is very important for the medical management of patients and to prevent the spread of the virus in the hospital setting to other hospitalized patients. Numerous viral antigen assays have been used to rapidly determine the cause of AVG (Table 2).

Several methodologies for the rapid detection of human RV, HAdv, HAsV, NoV, and SaV antigens from patient stool samples have been developed. These include enzyme immunoassay (EIA), latex particle agglutination (LA), immunochromatography test (ICT), and more recently, chemiluminescent immunoassay (CLIA) (115). The rapid antigen assays, in particular the RV assays, are widely used as point-of-care (POC) assays in hospital settings and can provide patient results within 30 minutes. Additionally, the low cost of these assays provides an advantage in the gastrointestinal diagnostic work-up. Antigen assays are more sensitive than the EM/IEM and tissue culture (4, 8, 32, 115, 130, 134). Rapid antigen detection assays are widely used in the pediatric setting, as patients shed large amounts of viral particles for several days during the acute phase of infection, thus increasing the sensitivity of these assays. However, a recent study comparing rapid antigen-detection kits against Reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) as the gold standard revealed that there was variable sensitivity and specificity for the detection of Revision (135). The sensitivity and specificity of the SD Bioline (Standard Diagnostics, Inc., South Korea), VIROTECT (Trinity Biotech, Ireland), Rota-Strip (C-1001) (Coris Bioconcept, Belgium), Acon (Acon Laboratories, Inc., San Diego, CA), and VIKIA Rota-Adeno (bioMérieux, France) kits ranged from 52.3 to 95.08% and 20 to 86.62%, respectively (135). The study clearly showed that clinical laboratories must perform in-house clinical validation of these rapid assays before including them in their test menu.

Conventional 96-well microplate EIAs for RV and HAdV are widely used due to their reasonably high sensitivity and specificity and consistent test results. EIAs that utilize monoclonal antibodies are widely used for the detection of group A and C RV in patient stool samples (136, 137). Similarly, EIAs have been developed for the rapid detection of astroviruses and caliciviruses using monoclonal antibodies. These assays had 2-fold greater sensitivity than EIA assays developed using polyclonal antibodies (138). Most of the HAdV EIAs detect a common group antigen, of which 45 to 95% occurring in stool samples are HAdV serotypes 40 and 41 (139).

The LA technique is widely used in the clinical setting for the identification of the majority of common human gastrointestinal viruses. Latex particles coated with antibodies against the different viruses agglutinate in the presence of the viral antigen in the patient stool sample (140–143). However, this technique is less sensitive than EM and EIA.

ICT is technically simple and is a rapid assay for the detection of common human gastrointestinal viruses, with similar clinical sensitivity as the EIA (144). ICTs are designed as dipsticks or self-contained cassettes and usually include a built-in positive control that can be used to determine that the reaction has been performed and interpreted accurately. ICT is of value for small to moderate-sized laboratories that need to diagnose sporadic AVG cases. ICT can be used in medical laboratories not equipped to carry out advanced diagnostic techniques because they are inexpensive and easy to use and provide rapid on-site results (145). ICT requires neither specific equipment nor advanced personnel training. One of the drawbacks of ICT is that often these assays suffer from low sensitivity, failing to produce positive results when the viral load in the patient stool sample is low (144, 145). In a recent study, when the RV/HAdV combo ICT assay performance was compared to PCR, the RV ICT assay gave comparable results; however, the HAdV assay was much less sensitive than PCR and could not be used as a first-line rapid screening tool for HAdV (145).

RV vaccination can impact the interpretation of antigen tests, as fecal shedding of RV vaccine may occur, especially in the first 9 days postvaccination. Physicians should be aware of the patient’s vaccination status and time of vaccine administration when interpreting positive results (146).

The CLIA technique is based on the capture of the viral antigen present in the stool sample by antibodies coupled with a molecule capable of emitting light during a chemical reaction (147). Light emission is used to measure the formation of antigen-antibody complex. Recently a CLIA-based assay for the detection of enteric adenoviruses showed better clinical sensitivity when compared to ICT (148).

sect1.title: Nucleic Acid Detection
sect1.para: Molecular diagnostic techniques have dramatically improved our understanding of the circulation of AVG-causing viruses. This in part was because of the advancement in developing and validating rapid and sensitive assays that detect multiple pathogens simultaneously. Molecular assays were classically designed to directly amplify specific viral genome sequences by PCR for DNA viruses and by RT-PCR for RNA viruses. One of the biggest challenges of performing these molecular assays from stool samples is coping with the PCR inhibitors present in the samples. Because inhibitors can lead to false-negative results, internal PCR assay controls have been utilized to assess the presence of PCR inhibitors.

sect2.title: Singleplex PCR and RT-PCR
sect2.para: Singleplex PCR and RT-PCR initially depended on the amplification and visualization of the viral amplicons in 1 to 2% agarose gels by electrophoresis and depended on the expected size of the amplified amplicon. The viral amplicon accumulates and plateaus as the thermal cycling goes to completion. Many singleplex (and multiplex) assays have been developed and validated for the detection of AVG pathogens (149–157). These assays are more sensitive than EM, tissue culture, and antigen-based assays. Classical PCR assays have advanced our knowledge of the circulation of AVG pathogens, but these assays were primarily developed to genotype the different pathogens. Many assays were developed and used to genotype RV, based on the amplification and sequencing of its VP4 (P-types) and VP7 (G-types) genes (158, 159). Similarly, these assays were extensively used to genotype NoV and SaV (8, 32, 160). While these classical PCR and RT-PCR assays have dramatically improved our understanding of the AVG pathogens, they were cumbersome to perform in the diagnostic laboratory, had relatively low throughput, and were typically “open systems” with increased chance of false-positive results due to amplicon contamination in the laboratory.

sect2.title: Real-Time PCR (qPCR or qRT-PCR)
sect2.para: Real-time PCR eliminated the need for visualizing the amplified amplicons by agarose gel electrophoresis and instead utilized fluorescently labeled probes to visualize the amplified amplicons while the reaction is running in real time. qPCR and qRT-PCR assays are currently the most used assays for the rapid and sensitive detection of AVG pathogens. These assays have reduced the hands-on time the technologist needs to spend in running the assays; they have higher throughput (generally up to 96 samples per run) and, in addition, eliminate the chance of false-positive results due to contamination, since the qPCR tubes are not opened and a charge-coupled device (CCD) camera reads the fluorescence generated from amplification of the pathogen amplicon. Additionally, the ability to use multiple fluorescent labels with different excitation wavelengths allowed for developing and validating multiplex assays for simultaneously detecting one to five pathogens in patient stool samples. Many laboratory-developed and commercial assays are currently available for the simultaneous detection of multiple AVG pathogens (161–171). These assays have excellent analytical sensitivity of <10 genome copies for rotavirus and noroviruses, in addition to excellent limits of quantification ranging over 7 to 8 log dilutions (161, 172–177). Several commercial CE-IVD and FDA-cleared kits are available for detecting different AVG pathogens. These include the Allplex Gastrointestinal Panel (Seegene, Korea); QIAstat-Dx Gastrointestinal Panel (Qiagen, Hilden, Germany); RIDA GENE real-time PCR kits (r-Biopharm AG, Darmstadt, Germany); EntericBio real-time Gastro (Serosep, Limerick, Ireland); GastroFinder 2SMART (PathoFinder, Maastricht, The Netherlands), BioFire FilmArray GI panel (bioMérieux/BioFire Diagnostics, Salt Lake City, UT), and xTAG Gastrointestinal Pathogen Panel, NxTAG Gastrointestinal Pathogen Panel, and Verigene Enteric Pathogens Test (Luminex, A DiaSorin Company, Austin, TX) (Table 3).

Currently, there is insufficient evidence to support routine use of gastrointestinal multiplex panels for determining the causative agent of AVG. However, the Infectious Diseases Society of America (IDSA) has recommended the utilization of diagnostic testing for patients with diarrheal disease and with bloody or mucoid stool, fever, severe abdominal cramping or tenderness, or signs of sepsis (7).

Depending on the panel, detecting the causative agent, whether viral or, in some panels, bacterial or parasitic, may help determine the causative agent in gastrointestinal infectious disease outbreaks.

The rapid diagnosis of the causative agent can help in cohorting infected patients and in following appropriate infection control measures if the outbreak occurred in hospitalized patients. In addition, determining the correct causative agent can help in reducing patient hospitalization length of stay and help physicians prescribe the appropriate antibiotic, thus avoiding antibiotic misuse. The IDSA guidelines recommend empirical treatment of immunocompromised patients or young infants with severe acute watery diarrhea, and thus determining the AVG causative agent will help in reducing antibiotic usage (7).

Physicians should be cautious when interpreting these panels’ results. With the widespread implementation of rotavirus vaccines, these multiplex molecular assays can detect the shedding of the rotavirus vaccine strains in patient stool samples (178). RV vaccine strains can be detected after the first RV vaccine dose; detection declines after the second and third RV doses. Physicians should be aware that RV vaccine strains, in particular G1, can be detected in patient stool samples by PCR for up to 2 weeks postvaccination. Ultimately, with the increasing use of these highly sensitive multiplex kits, our understanding of the clinical presentation and corresponding pathogens and the epidemiology of these agents will improve.

sect2.title: Droplet Digital PCR
sect2.para: Digital PCR allows for the direct quantification of amplified nucleic acid. This technology has not been used by commercial companies to develop diagnostic assays for AVG, in part because quantitation of these pathogens in patient stool samples is not clinically needed. However, interest in quantifying AVG causing pathogens in sewage samples and food products (oysters, lettuce, and strawberries) was reported for RV, NoV, and HAdV (179–183).

sect2.title: Isothermal Nucleic Acid Amplification-Based Assays
sect2.para: Several isothermal amplification chemistries have been used for the detection of different viral pathogens. However, several of these assays are not widely available in the clinical laboratory (except as laboratory-developed tests) and are mainly used for research. These isothermal amplification chemistries include the following.

sect3.title: Nucleic Acid Sequence-Based Amplification (NASBA)
sect3.para: NASBA is a two-step process that involves denaturation followed by temperature-labile polymerase-dependent isothermal amplification of the target gene. Developed and validated assays based on NASBA showed excellent analytical sensitivity for the detection of RV, NoV, and AsV. The limit of detection (LOD) was 7, 100, and 200 copies per reaction for RV, NoV, and AsV, respectively (184). Because of the isothermal nature of NASBA assays, there are several advantages over thermal amplification assays including the absence of a need for a thermocycler, less hands-on time, and less labor for setting up the reactions (185–187).

sect3.title: Loop-Mediated Isothermal Amplification (LAMP)
sect3.para: LAMP is a rapid, inexpensive, and accurate diagnostic method that selectively amplifies the target gene under isothermal conditions, generally around 60°C. Reverse transcription LAMP assays were developed for the detection of RV and NoV and showed clinical sensitivity comparable to commercial RT-PCR kits (188, 189). The sensitivity of RT-LAMP for the detection of RV was reported to be 104 copies (190). More recently, a simple paper-based assay for the diagnosis of RV using the isothermal amplification technique (paper-LAMP) was developed. Nucleic acid extraction can be accomplished within 5 minutes and then followed by target sequence amplification for 25 minutes. The RV assay result can be visible immediately afterwards or can be quantitated using UV-visible spectroscopy. The limit of detection of the RV assay was found to be 103 copies/ml (191).

sect3.title: Recombinase Polymerase Amplification (RPA)
sect3.para: RPA utilizes bacterial recombinase and binding proteins and is generally carried out at a slightly higher than normal temperature, since a low temperature can produce nonspecific amplification artifacts. The entire amplification and analysis takes about 30 minutes and does not need any thermal denaturation of the template. The cost-effectiveness, portability, simplicity, analytical sensitivity, and tolerance to inhibitors potentially make this assay an attractive method for the rapid diagnosis of AVG. RPA assays have been developed for the detection of NoV (192).

sect1.title: Next-Generation Sequencing
sect1.para: It is estimated that approximately 40% of AVG cases have an unknown etiological agent (193). This could be in part due to the presence of undiscovered viruses or even novel variants of viral pathogens that cause gastroenteritis. The advent of next-generation sequencing (NGS) technologies has opened new opportunities for detection and discovery of viral pathogens in a well-equipped clinical or referral laboratory setting (194). NGS has already been used extensively to determine the cause of unsolved outbreaks of gastroenteritis in humans (195). In a recent study of stool samples from patients who tested negative for common AVG viruses, the most abundant sequences detected that were potentially associated with AVG included members of the Astroviridae and Caliciviridae families, in addition to NoV and SaV and other viruses that may cause AVG, such as members of the Picornaviridae family and adenoviruses (196). Currently, NGS procedures have been primarily used as a research tool. In a clinical virology laboratory with limited resources, setting up NGS platforms currently remains a big challenge due to the initial cost of the equipment, turnaround time, and the requirement for powerful computational abilities with skilled laboratory and bioinformatics personnel.

sect2.title: ISOLATION PROCEDURES
sect2.para: Tissue culture is not considered a useful technique for the diagnosis of AVG pathogens, and it is mainly used in research. Viral isolation is technically demanding and cumbersome, some of the viruses are slow to grow, and some do not grow in tissue culture, such as caliciviruses (197). Recent reports indicated that the utilization of bile acid allowed SaV, a calicivirus, to grow in the human cell lines NEC8 (testis) and HuTu80 (duodenum). The availability of tissue culture cell lines to propagate some of these viruses has allowed an exponential expansion of our understanding of these pathogens and has allowed for the production of reagents for diagnosis of these agents. RV propagation in primary cells (African green and cynomolgus monkey kidney) directly from stool samples has been more efficient than propagation in continuous cell lines like African green (CV-1) or rhesus (MA104) monkey kidney cells (198). It is important to note that different RV strains vary in their capacity to grow in tissue culture (198). To culture RV, culture medium must be supplemented with proteases such as trypsin or pancreatin. HAsVs have been reported to be cultivated in a variety of human and monkey cell lines; however, these cells are not permissive to all HAsV genotypes. HAdV 40/41 can be cultivated in variety of cell lines (HeLa, HEp-2, HEK293, CaCo-2, and PLC/PRF/5 cells). However, the growth in these cell lines can be slow, thus allowing other viruses to overgrow the HAdV.

Tissue culture diagnostic assays must be complemented with another diagnostic tool, such as molecular or immunofluorescence assays, to determine the type of virus that was cultured, which further delays the viral diagnosis.

sect2.title: SEROLOGICAL TESTS
sect2.para: Serological assays have not been widely used for the routine diagnosis of AVG pathogens. Indeed, serological assays have been mainly used to perform serosurveillance studies (199–201). ELISA-based assays that utilize specific viral proteins for the detection of different viral antibodies have been widely used in epidemiological studies of gastrointestinal viruses such as RV, NoV, and AsV (32, 202, 203). ELISA assays have been used for monitoring patients’ seroconversion, based on a collection of acute- and convalescent-phase sera during outbreak investigations.

Several new antibody-measuring technologies have been developed and validated for the detection of AVG pathogens. Biolayer interferometry immunosorbent assay (BLI-ISA) was recently reported to measure the blood plasma IgG antibodies directed against HAsV capsid spike from serotypes 1 through 8 (204). The luciferase immunoprecipitation system (LIPS) assay, a liquid-phase immunoassay that quantifies antigen-specific serum antibodies, has also been used for the quantitation of NoV antibodies (205). The LIPS assay can be used as a high-throughput assay for quantitating serum antibodies that recognize diverse viral antigens.

Antibody-neutralization assays that are based on plaque reduction, or epitope-blocking assays using virus-specific monoclonal antibodies, have been described for some of the gastrointestinal viruses like RV and NoV (206–209). Antibody-neutralization assays have also been used for evaluating antibodies induced post RV vaccination (207, 210).

sect2.title: EVALUATION, INTERPRETATION, AND REPORTING OF RESULTS
sect2.para: Laboratory diagnosis of the causative agent of AVG has been hampered by multiple factors. Initially, physicians depended on empirical judgment to diagnose most AVG, and thus many cases of AVG went unrecognized. Also, because of the self-limiting nature of the illness, short duration of the infection, and absence of specific clinical management of the patients, physicians opt not to look for the viral pathogen causing the disease. The high cost of many commercial assays is another factor prohibiting physicians from requesting laboratory tests to diagnose the AVG pathogen.

Laboratory confirmation of AVG can be accomplished by using viral antigen detection assays, molecular diagnostic assays, and to much less extent, serology or viral culture (Tables 2 and 3). Both serological assays and tissue culture have not been used in the routine laboratory diagnosis of AVG. Serological AVG assays have mainly been used for enteric virus seroepidemiological studies, while tissue culture has not been routinely used because AVG pathogens do not grow well in cell culture.

Commercially available antigen assays for the rapid detection of RV and, to a lesser extent, HAdV 40/41, NoVs, SaVs, and AsVs allow for the rapid diagnosis of AVG. While these assays are inexpensive, easy to use, and widely available, they generally lack sensitivity and specificity. The moderate sensitivity may be a practical choice for the initial screening of patient stool samples if the tests are available for specific viruses, such as rotavirus.

Rotavirus antigen detection assays in the pediatric setting have played an important role in the rapid diagnosis of rotavirus infections. This has allowed infection control coordinators to rapidly isolate and cohort RV-infected patients, thus preventing the spread of the infection in the hospital setting (211). Similar observations were noted for NoV spread in the hospital setting. Several studies have also shown that rapid diagnosis of NoV allowed for the rapid implementation of infection control measures, thus reducing the number of hospital-acquired infections and shortening the duration of an NoV outbreak (55–57).

The integration of commercially available molecular assays for the detection of multiple fecal viral pathogens has started to replace the traditional assays in many settings. The availability of multiplex PCR assays has also opened the door for better understanding of the epidemiology and the disease patterns of the different enteric viral pathogens in a particular setting. The major advantage of molecular diagnostic methods is the increased sensitivity and specificity for common viruses, such as rotaviruses and adenoviruses, and the ability to detect uncultivable viruses such as noroviruses, astroviruses, and sapoviruses. However, the high sensitivity and specificity of molecular assays have complicated the interpretation of patient results, as frequent detection of viral genomes in the fecal samples of asymptomatic patients has been observed and detection of viral nucleic acid does not necessarily indicate viability. Also unclear is the clinical significance of detecting multiple pathogens in patient stool samples. Physicians should also be aware that patients with multiple viral pathogens could have been exposed to a common source of infection, such as in areas with poor water and sewage handling.
